page.title: 01A brief history of Trecastle
page.content: Trecastle Village Trecastle may or may not have been a typical Welsh rural village. It was situated on the main London to Fishguard road but twelve miles from the county town of Brecon-three miles from the nearest railway station and nine miles from the Carmarthenshire town of Llandovery. It was insular. In the early nineteenth century it was serviced by the Mail coach which left the Castle Hotel Brecon at 9.2O a.m. and returned to that place at 12.2O p.m.. When the Brecon-Neath Railway was opened in 1864 there was a mail bus between Llandovery and Defynnock which met the 8.35 a.m. train from Brecon and the 4.35 p.m. train from Neath. in some ways the village was self supporting.
